🛠️ 2025 Must-Know Tools for Data Engineers: Snowflake and DatabricksIf you’re in the data space, chances are you’ve seen job ads mentioning Snowflake or Databricks and sometimes both. But which one should you focus on? I recently had an aspiring Data Engineer ask me this very question, so I followed up with a few client partners to get their thoughts. From my conversations, here are a few key takeaways: ❄️  Snowflake is excelling where businesses need fast, scalable cloud data warehousing with less engineering complexity. It’s popular with teams focused on analytics, BI, and SQL-heavy workflows. If you're strong in SQL, dbt, or have worked with Power BI/Tableau, Snowflake experience is a huge plus.🔥 Databricks is preferred by businesses venturing into deeper machine learning, real-time processing, or working with large, messy datasets. It’s more engineering-heavy. Python, Spark, Delta Lake, and a bit more config. Employers are increasingly asking for either, both or at least an understanding of how they complement each other. Snowflake for clean, structured data; Databricks for the heavy lifting in transformation and modelling.If you’re an engineer or analyst wondering where to invest your learning hours.➡️ Want to stay close to BI, analytics or SQL? Have a look at Snowflake.➡️ More into data engineering, ML, or AI workflows? Take a squiz at Databricks.👉 Call to Action:It seems whether you're hiring, upskilling, or exploring tools for your next project, understanding where each fits can play a big role in your growth or data strategy.If you’re on the lookout for your next role or hiring right now - whether it’s around Snowflake, Databricks, or anything else data-related, please don’t hesitate to reach out. I’m always happy to chat and share updates.

🛠️ 2025 Must-Know Tools for Data Engineers: Snowflake and DatabricksIf you’re in the data space, chances are you’ve seen job ads mentioning Snowflake or Databricks and sometimes both. But which one should you focus on? I recently had an aspiring Data Engineer ask me this very question, so I followed up with a few client partners to get their thoughts. From my conversations, here are a few key takeaways: ❄️  Snowflake is excelling where businesses need fast, scalable cloud data warehousing with less engineering complexity. It’s popular with teams focused on analytics, BI, and SQL-heavy workflows. If you're strong in SQL, dbt, or have worked with Power BI/Tableau, Snowflake experience is a huge plus.🔥 Databricks is preferred by businesses venturing into deeper machine learning, real-time processing, or working with large, messy datasets. It’s more engineering-heavy. Python, Spark, Delta Lake, and a bit more config. Employers are increasingly asking for either, both or at least an understanding of how they complement each other. Snowflake for clean, structured data; Databricks for the heavy lifting in transformation and modelling.If you’re an engineer or analyst wondering where to invest your learning hours.➡️ Want to stay close to BI, analytics or SQL? Have a look at Snowflake.➡️ More into data engineering, ML, or AI workflows? Take a squiz at Databricks.👉 Call to Action:It seems whether you're hiring, upskilling, or exploring tools for your next project, understanding where each fits can play a big role in your growth or data strategy.If you’re on the lookout for your next role or hiring right now - whether it’s around Snowflake, Databricks, or anything else data-related, please don’t hesitate to reach out. I’m always happy to chat and share updates.

🛠️ 2025 Must-Know Tools for Data Engineers: Snowflake and DatabricksIf you’re in the data space, chances are you’ve seen job ads mentioning Snowflake or Databricks and sometimes both. But which one should you focus on? I recently had an aspiring Data Engineer ask me this very question, so I followed up with a few client partners to get their thoughts. From my conversations, here are a few key takeaways: ❄️  Snowflake is excelling where businesses need fast, scalable cloud data warehousing with less engineering complexity. It’s popular with teams focused on analytics, BI, and SQL-heavy workflows. If you're strong in SQL, dbt, or have worked with Power BI/Tableau, Snowflake experience is a huge plus.🔥 Databricks is preferred by businesses venturing into deeper machine learning, real-time processing, or working with large, messy datasets. It’s more engineering-heavy. Python, Spark, Delta Lake, and a bit more config. Employers are increasingly asking for either, both or at least an understanding of how they complement each other. Snowflake for clean, structured data; Databricks for the heavy lifting in transformation and modelling.If you’re an engineer or analyst wondering where to invest your learning hours.➡️ Want to stay close to BI, analytics or SQL? Have a look at Snowflake.➡️ More into data engineering, ML, or AI workflows? Take a squiz at Databricks.👉 Call to Action:It seems whether you're hiring, upskilling, or exploring tools for your next project, understanding where each fits can play a big role in your growth or data strategy.If you’re on the lookout for your next role or hiring right now - whether it’s around Snowflake, Databricks, or anything else data-related, please don’t hesitate to reach out. I’m always happy to chat and share updates.

🛠️ 2025 Must-Know Tools for Data Engineers: Snowflake and DatabricksIf you’re in the data space, chances are you’ve seen job ads mentioning Snowflake or Databricks and sometimes both. But which one should you focus on? I recently had an aspiring Data Engineer ask me this very question, so I followed up with a few client partners to get their thoughts. From my conversations, here are a few key takeaways: ❄️  Snowflake is excelling where businesses need fast, scalable cloud data warehousing with less engineering complexity. It’s popular with teams focused on analytics, BI, and SQL-heavy workflows. If you're strong in SQL, dbt, or have worked with Power BI/Tableau, Snowflake experience is a huge plus.🔥 Databricks is preferred by businesses venturing into deeper machine learning, real-time processing, or working with large, messy datasets. It’s more engineering-heavy. Python, Spark, Delta Lake, and a bit more config. Employers are increasingly asking for either, both or at least an understanding of how they complement each other. Snowflake for clean, structured data; Databricks for the heavy lifting in transformation and modelling.If you’re an engineer or analyst wondering where to invest your learning hours.➡️ Want to stay close to BI, analytics or SQL? Have a look at Snowflake.➡️ More into data engineering, ML, or AI workflows? Take a squiz at Databricks.👉 Call to Action:It seems whether you're hiring, upskilling, or exploring tools for your next project, understanding where each fits can play a big role in your growth or data strategy.If you’re on the lookout for your next role or hiring right now - whether it’s around Snowflake, Databricks, or anything else data-related, please don’t hesitate to reach out. I’m always happy to chat and share updates.

🛠️ 2025 Must-Know Tools for Data Engineers: Snowflake and DatabricksIf you’re in the data space, chances are you’ve seen job ads mentioning Snowflake or Databricks and sometimes both. But which one should you focus on? I recently had an aspiring Data Engineer ask me this very question, so I followed up with a few client partners to get their thoughts. From my conversations, here are a few key takeaways: ❄️  Snowflake is excelling where businesses need fast, scalable cloud data warehousing with less engineering complexity. It’s popular with teams focused on analytics, BI, and SQL-heavy workflows. If you're strong in SQL, dbt, or have worked with Power BI/Tableau, Snowflake experience is a huge plus.🔥 Databricks is preferred by businesses venturing into deeper machine learning, real-time processing, or working with large, messy datasets. It’s more engineering-heavy. Python, Spark, Delta Lake, and a bit more config. Employers are increasingly asking for either, both or at least an understanding of how they complement each other. Snowflake for clean, structured data; Databricks for the heavy lifting in transformation and modelling.If you’re an engineer or analyst wondering where to invest your learning hours.➡️ Want to stay close to BI, analytics or SQL? Have a look at Snowflake.➡️ More into data engineering, ML, or AI workflows? Take a squiz at Databricks.👉 Call to Action:It seems whether you're hiring, upskilling, or exploring tools for your next project, understanding where each fits can play a big role in your growth or data strategy.If you’re on the lookout for your next role or hiring right now - whether it’s around Snowflake, Databricks, or anything else data-related, please don’t hesitate to reach out. I’m always happy to chat and share updates.

🛠️ 2025 Must-Know Tools for Data Engineers: Snowflake and DatabricksIf you’re in the data space, chances are you’ve seen job ads mentioning Snowflake or Databricks and sometimes both. But which one should you focus on? I recently had an aspiring Data Engineer ask me this very question, so I followed up with a few client partners to get their thoughts. From my conversations, here are a few key takeaways: ❄️  Snowflake is excelling where businesses need fast, scalable cloud data warehousing with less engineering complexity. It’s popular with teams focused on analytics, BI, and SQL-heavy workflows. If you're strong in SQL, dbt, or have worked with Power BI/Tableau, Snowflake experience is a huge plus.🔥 Databricks is preferred by businesses venturing into deeper machine learning, real-time processing, or working with large, messy datasets. It’s more engineering-heavy. Python, Spark, Delta Lake, and a bit more config. Employers are increasingly asking for either, both or at least an understanding of how they complement each other. Snowflake for clean, structured data; Databricks for the heavy lifting in transformation and modelling.If you’re an engineer or analyst wondering where to invest your learning hours.➡️ Want to stay close to BI, analytics or SQL? Have a look at Snowflake.➡️ More into data engineering, ML, or AI workflows? Take a squiz at Databricks.👉 Call to Action:It seems whether you're hiring, upskilling, or exploring tools for your next project, understanding where each fits can play a big role in your growth or data strategy.If you’re on the lookout for your next role or hiring right now - whether it’s around Snowflake, Databricks, or anything else data-related, please don’t hesitate to reach out. I’m always happy to chat and share updates.

🛠️ 2025 Must-Know Tools for Data Engineers: Snowflake and DatabricksIf you’re in the data space, chances are you’ve seen job ads mentioning Snowflake or Databricks and sometimes both. But which one should you focus on? I recently had an aspiring Data Engineer ask me this very question, so I followed up with a few client partners to get their thoughts. From my conversations, here are a few key takeaways: ❄️  Snowflake is excelling where businesses need fast, scalable cloud data warehousing with less engineering complexity. It’s popular with teams focused on analytics, BI, and SQL-heavy workflows. If you're strong in SQL, dbt, or have worked with Power BI/Tableau, Snowflake experience is a huge plus.🔥 Databricks is preferred by businesses venturing into deeper machine learning, real-time processing, or working with large, messy datasets. It’s more engineering-heavy. Python, Spark, Delta Lake, and a bit more config. Employers are increasingly asking for either, both or at least an understanding of how they complement each other. Snowflake for clean, structured data; Databricks for the heavy lifting in transformation and modelling.If you’re an engineer or analyst wondering where to invest your learning hours.➡️ Want to stay close to BI, analytics or SQL? Have a look at Snowflake.➡️ More into data engineering, ML, or AI workflows? 🛠️ 2025 Must-Know Tools for Data Engineers: Snowflake and DatabricksIf you’re in the data space, chances are you’ve seen job ads mentioning Snowflake or Databricks and sometimes both. But which one should you focus on? I recently had an aspiring Data Engineer ask me this very question, so I followed up with a few client partners to get their thoughts. From my conversations, here are a few key takeaways: ❄️  Snowflake is excelling where businesses need fast, scalable cloud data warehousing with less engineering complexity. It’s popular with teams focused on analytics, BI, and SQL-heavy workflows. If you're strong in SQL, dbt, or have worked with Power BI/Tableau, Snowflake experience is a huge plus.🔥 Databricks is preferred by businesses venturing into deeper machine learning, real-time processing, or working with large, messy datasets. It’s more engineering-heavy. Python, Spark, Delta Lake, and a bit more config. Employers are increasingly asking for either, both or at least an understanding of how they complement each other. Snowflake for clean, structured data; Databricks for the heavy lifting in transformation and modelling.If you’re an engineer or analyst wondering where to invest your learning hours.➡️ Want to stay close to BI, analytics or SQL? Have a look at Snowflake.➡️ More into data engineering, ML, or AI workflows? Take a squiz at Databricks.👉 Call to Action:It seems whether you're hiring, upskilling, or exploring tools for your next project, understanding where each fits can play a big role in your growth or data strategy.If you’re on the lookout for your next role or hiring right now - whether it’s around Snowflake, Databricks, or anything else data-related, please don’t hesitate to reach out. I’m always happy to chat and share updates.

🛠️ 2025 Must-Know Tools for Data Engineers: Snowflake and DatabricksIf you’re in the data space, chances are you’ve seen job ads mentioning Snowflake or Databricks and sometimes both. But which one should you focus on? I recently had an aspiring Data Engineer ask me this very question, so I followed up with a few client partners to get their thoughts. From my conversations, here are a few key takeaways: ❄️  Snowflake is excelling where businesses need fast, scalable cloud data warehousing with less engineering complexity. It’s popular with teams focused on analytics, BI, and SQL-heavy workflows. If you're strong in SQL, dbt, or have worked with Power BI/Tableau, Snowflake experience is a huge plus.🔥 Databricks is preferred by businesses venturing into deeper machine learning, real-time processing, or working with large, messy datasets. It’s more engineering-heavy. Python, Spark, Delta Lake, and a bit more config. Employers are increasingly asking for either, both or at least an understanding of how they complement each other. Snowflake for clean, structured data; Databricks for the heavy lifting in transformation and modelling.If you’re an engineer or analyst wondering where to invest your learning hours.➡️ Want to stay close to BI, analytics or SQL? Have a look at Snowflake.➡️ More into data engineering, ML, or AI workflows? Take a squiz at Databricks.👉 Call to Action:It seems whether you're hiring, upskilling, or exploring tools for your next project, understanding where each fits can play a big role in your growth or data strategy.If you’re on the lookout for your next role or hiring right now - whether it’s around Snowflake, Databricks, or anything else data-related, please don’t hesitate to reach out. I’m always happy to chat and share updates.

🛠️ 2025 Must-Know Tools for Data Engineers: Snowflake and DatabricksIf you’re in the data space, chances are you’ve seen job ads mentioning Snowflake or Databricks and sometimes both. But which one should you focus on? I recently had an aspiring Data Engineer ask me this very question, so I followed up with a few client partners to get their thoughts. From my conversations, here are a few key takeaways: ❄️  Snowflake is excelling where businesses need fast, scalable cloud data warehousing with less engineering complexity. It’s popular with teams focused on analytics, BI, and SQL-heavy workflows. If you're strong in SQL, dbt, or have worked with Power BI/Tableau, Snowflake experience is a huge plus.🔥 Databricks is preferred by businesses venturing into deeper machine learning, real-time processing, or working with large, messy datasets. It’s more engineering-heavy. Python, Spark, Delta Lake, and a bit more config. Employers are increasingly asking for either, both or at least an understanding of how they complement each other. Snowflake for clean, structured data; Databricks for the heavy lifting in transformation and modelling.If you’re an engineer or analyst wondering where to invest your learning hours.➡️ Want to stay close to BI, analytics or SQL? Have a look at Snowflake.➡️ More into data engineering, ML, or AI workflows? Take a squiz at Databricks.👉 Call to Action:It seems whether you're hiring, upskilling, or exploring tools for your next project, understanding where each fits can play a big role in your growth or data strategy.If you’re on the lookout for your next role or hiring right now - whether it’s around Snowflake, Databricks, or anything else data-related, please don’t hesitate to reach out. I’m always happy to chat and share updates.

🛠️ 2025 Must-Know Tools for Data Engineers: Snowflake and DatabricksIf you’re in the data space, chances are you’ve seen job ads mentioning Snowflake or Databricks and sometimes both. But which one should you focus on? I recently had an aspiring Data Engineer ask me this very question, so I followed up with a few client partners to get their thoughts. From my conversations, here are a few key takeaways: ❄️  Snowflake is excelling where businesses need fast, scalable cloud data warehousing with less engineering complexity. It’s popular with teams focused on analytics, BI, and SQL-heavy workflows. If you're strong in SQL, dbt, or have worked with Power BI/Tableau, Snowflake experience is a huge plus.🔥 Databricks is preferred by businesses venturing into deeper machine learning, real-time processing, or working with large, messy datasets. It’s more engineering-heavy. Python, Spark, Delta Lake, and a bit more config. Employers are increasingly asking for either, both or at least an understanding of how they complement each other. Snowflake for clean, structured data; Databricks for the heavy lifting in transformation and modelling.If you’re an engineer or analyst wondering where to invest your learning hours.➡️ Want to stay close to BI, analytics or SQL? Have a look at Snowflake.➡️ More into data engineering, ML, or AI workflows? Take a squiz at Databricks.👉 Call to Action:It seems whether you're hiring, upskilling, or exploring tools for your next project, understanding where each fits can play a big role in your growth or data strategy.If you’re on the lookout for your next role or hiring right now - whether it’s around Snowflake, Databricks, or anything else data-related, please don’t hesitate to reach out. I’m always happy to chat and share updates.

🛠️ 2025 Must-Know Tools for Data Engineers: Snowflake and DatabricksIf you’re in the data space, chances are you’ve seen job ads mentioning Snowflake or Databricks and sometimes both. But which one should you focus on? I recently had an aspiring Data Engineer ask me this very question, so I followed up with a few client partners to get their thoughts. From my conversations, here are a few key takeaways: ❄️  Snowflake is excelling where businesses need fast, scalable cloud data warehousing with less engineering complexity. It’s popular with teams focused on analytics, BI, and SQL-heavy workflows. If you're strong in SQL, dbt, or have worked with Power BI/Tableau, Snowflake experience is a huge plus.🔥 Databricks is preferred by businesses venturing into deeper machine learning, real-time processing, or working with large, messy datasets. It’s more engineering-heavy. Python, Spark, Delta Lake, and a bit more config. Employers are increasingly asking for either, both or at least an understanding of how they complement each other. Snowflake for clean, structured data; Databricks for the heavy lifting in transformation and modelling.If you’re an engineer or analyst wondering where to invest your learning hours.➡️ Want to stay close to BI, analytics or SQL? Have a look at Snowflake.➡️ More into data engineering, ML, or AI workflows? Take a squiz at Databricks.👉 Call to Action:It seems whether you're hiring, upskilling, or exploring tools for your next project, understanding where each fits can play a big role in your growth or data strategy.If you’re on the lookout for your next role or hiring right now - whether it’s around Snowflake, Databricks, or anything else data-related, please don’t hesitate to reach out. I’m always happy to chat and share updates.

🛠️ 2025 Must-Know Tools for Data Engineers: Snowflake and DatabricksIf you’re in the data space, chances are you’ve seen job ads mentioning Snowflake or Databricks and sometimes both. But which one should you focus on? I recently had an aspiring Data Engineer ask me this very question, so I followed up with a few client partners to get their thoughts. From my conversations, here are a few key takeaways: ❄️  Snowflake is excelling where businesses need fast, scalable cloud data warehousing with less engineering complexity. It’s popular with teams focused on analytics, BI, and SQL-heavy workflows. If you're strong in SQL, dbt, or have worked with Power BI/Tableau, Snowflake experience is a huge plus.🔥 Databricks is preferred by businesses venturing into deeper machine learning, real-time processing, or working with large, messy datasets. It’s more engineering-heavy. Python, Spark, Delta Lake, and a bit more config. Employers are increasingly asking for either, both or at least an understanding of how they complement each other. Snowflake for clean, structured data; Databricks for the heavy lifting in transformation and modelling.If you’re an engineer or analyst wondering where to invest your learning hours.➡️ Want to stay close to BI, analytics or SQL? Have a look at Snowflake.➡️ More into data engineering, ML, or AI workflows? Take a squiz at Databricks.👉 Call to Action:It seems whether you're hiring, upskilling, or exploring tools for your next project, understanding where each fits can play a big role in your growth or data strategy.If you’re on the lookout for your next role or hiring right now - whether it’s around Snowflake, Databricks, or anything else data-related, please don’t hesitate to reach out. I’m always happy to chat and share updates.

🛠️ 2025 Must-Know Tools for Data Engineers: Snowflake and DatabricksIf you’re in the data space, chances are you’ve seen job ads mentioning Snowflake or Databricks and sometimes both. But which one should you focus on? I recently had an aspiring Data Engineer ask me this very question, so I followed up with a few client partners to get their thoughts. From my conversations, here are a few key takeaways: ❄️  Snowflake is excelling where businesses need fast, scalable cloud data warehousing with less engineering complexity. It’s popular with teams focused on analytics, BI, and SQL-heavy workflows. If you're strong in SQL, dbt, or have worked with Power BI/Tableau, Snowflake experience is a huge plus.🔥 Databricks is preferred by businesses venturing into deeper machine learning, real-time processing, or working with large, messy datasets. It’s more engineering-heavy. Python, Spark, Delta Lake, and a bit more config. Employers are increasingly asking for either, both or at least an understanding of how they complement each other. Snowflake for clean, structured data; Databricks for the heavy lifting in transformation and modelling.If you’re an engineer or analyst wondering where to invest your learning hours.➡️ Want to stay close to BI, analytics or SQL? Have a look at Snowflake.➡️ More into data engineering, ML, or AI workflows? Take a squiz at Databricks.👉 Call to Action:It seems whether you're hiring, upskilling, or exploring tools for your next project, understanding where each fits can play a big role in your growth or data strategy.If you’re on the lookout for your next role or hiring right now - whether it’s around Snowflake, Databricks, or anything else data-related, please don’t hesitate to reach out. I’m always happy to chat and share updates.

🛠️ 2025 Must-Know Tools for Data Engineers: Snowflake and DatabricksIf you’re in the data space, chances are you’ve seen job ads mentioning Snowflake or Databricks and sometimes both. But which one should you focus on? I recently had an aspiring Data Engineer ask me this very question, so I followed up with a few client partners to get their thoughts. From my conversations, here are a few key takeaways: ❄️  Snowflake is excelling where businesses need fast, scalable cloud data warehousing with less engineering complexity. It’s popular with teams focused on analytics, BI, and SQL-heavy workflows. If you're strong in SQL, dbt, or have worked with Power BI/Tableau, Snowflake experience is a huge plus.🔥 Databricks is preferred by businesses venturing into deeper machine learning, real-time processing, or working with large, messy datasets. It’s more engineering-heavy. Python, Spark, Delta Lake, and a bit more config. Employers are increasingly asking for either, both or at least an understanding of how they complement each other. Snowflake for clean, structured data; Databricks for the heavy lifting in transformation and modelling.If you’re an engineer or analyst wondering where to invest your learning hours.➡️ Want to stay close to BI, analytics or SQL? Have a look at Snowflake.➡️ More into data engineering, ML, or AI workflows? Take a squiz at Databricks.👉 Call to Action:It seems whether you're hiring, upskilling, or exploring tools for your next project, understanding where each fits can play a big role in your growth or data strategy.If you’re on the lookout for your next role or hiring right now - whether it’s around Snowflake, Databricks, or anything else data-related, please don’t hesitate to reach out. I’m always happy to chat and share updates.

🛠️ 2025 Must-Know Tools for Data Engineers: Snowflake and DatabricksIf you’re in the data space, chances are you’ve seen job ads mentioning Snowflake or Databricks and sometimes both. But which one should you focus on? I recently had an aspiring Data Engineer ask me this very question, so I followed up with a few client partners to get their thoughts. From my conversations, here are a few key takeaways: ❄️  Snowflake is excelling where businesses need fast, scalable cloud data warehousing with less engineering complexity. It’s popular with teams focused on analytics, BI, and SQL-heavy workflows. If you're strong in SQL, dbt, or have worked with Power BI/Tableau, Snowflake experience is a huge plus.🔥 Databricks is preferred by businesses venturing into deeper machine learning, real-time processing, or working with large, messy datasets. It’s more engineering-heavy. Python, Spark, Delta Lake, and a bit more config. Employers are increasingly asking for either, both or at least an understanding of how they complement each other. Snowflake for clean, structured data; Databricks for the heavy lifting in transformation and modelling.If you’re an engineer or analyst wondering where to invest your learning hours.➡️ Want to stay close to BI, analytics or SQL? Have a look at Snowflake.➡️ More into data engineering, ML, or AI workflows? Take a squiz at Databricks.👉 Call to Action:It seems whether you're hiring, upskilling, or exploring tools for your next project, understanding where each fits can play a big role in your growth or data strategy.If you’re on the lookout for your next role or hiring right now - whether it’s around Snowflake, Databricks, or anything else data-related, please don’t hesitate to reach out. I’m always happy to chat and share updates.

🛠️ 2025 Must-Know Tools for Data Engineers: Snowflake and DatabricksIf you’re in the data space, chances are you’ve seen job ads mentioning Snowflake or Databricks and sometimes both. But which one should you focus on? I recently had an aspiring Data Engineer ask me this very question, so I followed up with a few client partners to get their thoughts. From my conversations, here are a few key takeaways: ❄️  Snowflake is excelling where businesses need fast, scalable cloud data warehousing with less engineering complexity. It’s popular with teams focused on analytics, BI, and SQL-heavy workflows. If you're strong in SQL, dbt, or have worked with Power BI/Tableau, Snowflake experience is a huge plus.🔥 Databricks is preferred by businesses venturing into deeper machine learning, real-time processing, or working with large, messy datasets. It’s more engineering-heavy. Python, Spark, Delta Lake, and a bit more config. Employers are increasingly asking for either, both or at least an understanding of how they complement each other. Snowflake for clean, structured data; Databricks for the heavy lifting in transformation and modelling.If you’re an engineer or analyst wondering where to invest your learning hours.➡️ Want to stay close to BI, analytics or SQL? Have a look at Snowflake.➡️ More into data engineering, ML, or AI workflows? Take a squiz at Databricks.👉 Call to Action:It seems whether you're hiring, upskilling, or exploring tools for your next project, understanding where each fits can play a big role in your growth or data strategy.If you’re on the lookout for your next role or hiring right now - whether it’s around Snowflake, Databricks, or anything else data-related, please don’t hesitate to reach out. I’m always happy to chat and share updates.
